comments.text:
+Solomon Gad It's crux of the problem isn't that homosexuals wants to force 
religious people to marry them, against their beliefs.
It's that they want to be able to be married period.
Starting their own church and performing a marriage ceremony will mean 
nothing, legally, if the state outlaws same-sex marriages.

Sure, there is civil union, but not all states have civil union, and in any 
case it is only recognized in the state where the union was made, as 
opposed to marriage that is recognized across all states.

A United States citizen who is married can sponsor his or her non-American 
opposite-sex spouse for immigration into this country. Those with Civil 
Unions have no such privilege.

Civil Unions are not recognized by the federal government, so couples would 
not be able to file joint-tax returns or be eligible for tax breaks or 
protections the government affords to married couples.

To sum up:
The list of legal problems with civil unions compared to marriage is long, 
not to mention, not having the dignity, clarity, security and power of the 
word “marriage.”

And as i said, setting up their own church will not work, if same-sex 
marriage is not recognized by the state, which is what the issue is about.
